time_trend_data.indicator_description: NYC enacted a local law in 2005 that requires city agencies to reduce use of toxic products to control pests, and to adopt “Best Practices” instead. Best practice products use active ingredients with very low toxicity or involve formulation or application methods that minimize potential exposure and environmental spread.
time_trend_data.indicator_name: NYC Agency Use of "Best Practice" Products

Compare.compare_type: Agency Use of Best Practice Products
Compare.graph_title: Trends in Agency Use of Best Practice Products 2008 to 2018

info.info_name: NYC Agency Use of "Best Practice" Products
info.info_how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications made by NYC agencies or their contractors that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; having the term bait or gel in the product name, or containing active ingredients boric acid, disodium octaborate tetrahydrate, sodium tetraborate (pentahydrate), indoxacarb, silica gel, diatomaceous earth, (Z)-9-tricosene, S-methoprene, spinosad, hydramethylnon, pyriproxyfen, or fipronil; and not containing active ingredients of the chemical classes pyrethrins, pyrethroids, N-methyl carbamates or organophosphorous compounds.
info.info_source: Bureau of Environmental Surveillance and Policy (BESP) Combined Analytic Data Set, New York City Pesticide Use Reporting System (NYCPURS)

info.info_name: NYC Agency Use of "Best Practice" Products
info.info_how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications made by the Department of Education (DOE) or its contractors that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; having the term bait or gel in the product name, or containing active ingredients boric acid, disodium octaborate tetrahydrate, sodium tetraborate (pentahydrate), indoxacarb, silica gel, diatomaceous earth, (Z)-9-tricosene, S-methoprene, spinosad, hydramethylnon, pyriproxyfen, or fipronil; and not containing active ingredients of the chemical classes pyrethrins, pyrethroids, N-methyl carbamates or organophosphorous compounds.
info.info_source: Bureau of Environmental Surveillance and Policy (BESP) Combined Analytic Data Set, New York City Pesticide Use Reporting System (NYCPURS)

info.info_name: NYC Agency Use of "Best Practice" Products
info.info_how_calculated: Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications made by the NYC Housing Authority (NYCHA) or its contractors that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; having the term bait or gel in the product name, or containing active ingredients boric acid, disodium octaborate tetrahydrate, sodium tetraborate (pentahydrate), indoxacarb, silica gel, diatomaceous earth, (Z)-9-tricosene, S-methoprene, spinosad, hydramethylnon, pyriproxyfen, or fipronil; and not containing active ingredients of the chemical classes pyrethrins, pyrethroids, N-methyl carbamates or organophosphorous compounds.
info.info_source: Bureau of Environmental Surveillance and Policy (BESP) Combined Analytic Data Set, New York City Pesticide Use Reporting System (NYCPURS)
